{{also|gleis|gléis}} ==German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|de|Geleise||Switzerland|Austria}} ===Etymology=== The contemporary form is shortened from the variant {{m|de|Geleise}}, from {{etyl|gmh|de}} {{m|de|geleis||track}}, itself pertaining to {{cog|gmh|leise}}, from {{cog|goh|leisa}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ɡlaɪ̯s/}} * {{audio|de|De-at-Gleis.ogg|Audio (Austria)}} * {{audio|de|De-Gleis.ogg|Audio}} * {{rhymes|de|aɪ̯s}} ===Noun=== {{de-noun|n|Gleises|Gleise}} # [[railway]] {{gloss|track on which trains run}} # (individual) [[track]] ====Usage notes==== * In German train stations, trains are announced as leaving from a numbered track, not a platform. Platforms ({{m|de|Bahnsteig|Bahnsteige}}) give access to one or two tracks, and are usually not numbered themselves. ====Declension==== {{de-decl-noun-n|es|e}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|entgleisen}} * {{l|de|Gleisbett}} ===See also=== * {{l|de|Bahnsteig}} * {{l|de|Eisenbahn}} * {{l|de|Schiene}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:de:Rail transportation]]
